comment: the first sentence would be preferred in natural speech
the second structure would be more natural in a sentence like “For breakfast Susie had bread and eggs.”
this is fine, but there is a prosodic break after “TV”
What the “rV” morpheme does is debatable. Might be a TAM marker or polarity-related.
“mana” can be left out here
The modal (“nwere ike”) seems to play a role here, “ma” itself does not seem to have a genuinely disjunctive meaning
Without the nwere ike it would sound more like a conditional clause
pronouns (“i”) have a different tone in the polar question
in the polar question the pronoun has to be there to carry the Q-tone
in the polar question the pronoun has to be there to carry the Q-tone
“abu” and “bu” are different forms of the same copular
would prefer to have the verb in the second conjunct, also: na is not good here
ok, this works
“mana” should be added, but the above could be uttered in some situations
“ma o bu” also wouldn’t work here
That’s okay
That works, too

ok, that works
that’s fine
that’s ok
